components.text: This section will introduce the concept of disability, what to expect from employers and how to improve people's awareness of your disability

list_elements.text: To provide a clear definition of the concept of disability.
To inform students on what kind of reasonable adjustments to expect from employers.
To provide students with a general overview of how to make contact with staff and disclose their disability.
To support students to understand their rights and responsibilities with respect to disclosure.

components.text: You are classed as disabled under the Equality Act 2010 if you have a physical or mental impairment which has a ‘substantial’ and ‘long-term’ negative effect on your ability to do normal daily activities.

list_elements.text: 'substantial’ means the effect is more than minor or trivial, eg it takes much longer than it usually would to complete a daily task like getting dressed
‘long-term’ means the effect persist for 12 months or more, eg a breathing condition that develops as a result of a lung infection

components.text: A progressive condition is one that gets worse over time and people with progressive conditions can be classed as disabled.
However, you automatically meet the disability definition under the Equality Act 2010 from the day you’re diagnosed with HIV infection, cancer or multiple sclerosis.

myths.myth: It’s still ok to refer to people who do not have a disability as ‘able-bodied’?
myths.fact: No. This term suggests all disabilities are physical and that disabled employees or job applicants are not capable. Instead, if it is really necessary to make the distinction, use the term ‘non-disabled’ for people who do not have a disability.

myths.myth: To be disabled, the person has to be in a wheelchair, or blind, or lost a limb, something like that.
myths.fact: The definition of disability in the Equality Act 2010 is very broad and can cover a very wide range of conditions – what the law calls ‘impairments’. And some are not obvious – such as some mental health conditions.

components.text: Employers must make reasonable adjustments to ensure workers with disabilities, or physical or mental health conditions, aren’t substantially disadvantaged in their jobs. These adjustments may include:

list_elements.text: changing the recruitment process so a candidate can be considered for a job
doing things another way, such as allowing someone with social anxiety disorder to have their own desk instead of hot-desking
making physical changes to the workplace, such as installing a ramp for a wheelchair user or an audio-visual fire alarm for a deaf person
allowing  a disabled person to work somewhere else, such as on the ground floor for a wheelchair user
changing their equipment, for instance providing a special keyboard for a person with arthritis
allowing employees who become disabled to make a phased return to work, including flexible hours or part-time working
offering employees training opportunities, recreation and refreshment facilities

components.text: Reasonable adjustments apply to all employers and even should be considered for students whilst on placements.

The Disabilities team and the Mental Health team at the university have lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. Please feel free to contact them for advice with any concerns you may have relating to workplace and the reasonable adjustments you may be able to make for students with a disability, SpLD or Mental Health needs. Please note we can only give specific student related advice if a student has disclosed their learning needs to us (see Disclosure-Procedure) and completed a data protection form.

It is the student’s choice to disclose their learning needs. For students who want to disclose, we recommend they do so at the earliest stage(on their application form) or contact the disabilities team. Disclosure means we can offer them support and advice and can discuss their needs and opportunities for adjustments with all those involved in their education.

It is an individual’s right not to disclose their learning need. If a student chooses not to disclose, we are unaware of their condition and any related difficulties, therefore we are unable to offer support or advice.
